title: How to Remove .Ds_Store Files on Mac OS X

steps.headline: To delete a corrupted .DS_Store file you will need to use Terminal.app.
steps.description: To do that you must be logged into Mac OS X as an administrator.

steps.headline: Open Terminal.
Give yourself super-user (root) permissions in Terminal so you can use the commands needed to delete some .DS_Store files.

methods.name: Navigate to the Folder with the Corrupted .DS_Store File

steps.headline: Method 1: Use the 'cd' (Change Directory) command along with the path to the folder in need of repair.
steps.description:
To translate what you do in Finder to a written path, start by clicking 'Macintosh HD' on your desktop. This will become '/'. Click the next folder. The name will follow the '/' so type another '/' before any more folder names. For example, if the folder you are having issues with is 'Macintosh HD' -> 'Applications', the path to this folder is '/Applications'. If the problem folder was the 'Utilities' folder inside 'Applications', the path would be '/Applications/Utilities'. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e7\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/e7\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Type cd /path (example: cd /Applications) then press Return.

steps.headline: Method 2: We can use the 'cd' command and drag the folder to terminal which automatically completes the path building process for you.
steps.description:
Type cd in terminal followed by a space{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Find the folder with the issue but DON'T OPEN IT, drag its icon into terminal. Watch it complete the path for you. Press Return.

steps.headline: Type rm -f .DS_Store and press Return.
steps.description: Terminal will ask for no confirmation and give no indication that this has been completed - it will only return a message if the command did not work.

steps.headline: You should now be able to navigate to the folder in finder and the issue should be corrected.

text:
Steps To delete a corrupted .DS_Store file you will need to use Terminal.app. To do that you must be logged into Mac OS X as an administrator. Open Terminal. Open a new finder window and navigate to the Applications folder on the left. (Alternately, when it says 'Finder' beside your Apple in the top left hand corner of the screen, select the 'Go' menu and click 'Applications'. ){"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/d6/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/d6/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Inside the Applications folder near the very bottom is the 'Utilities' folder. Open that folder. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7c/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/7/7c/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Find and double-click the 'Terminal' application with the left mouse button to open it. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a6/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/a/a6/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.6666666666667,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Give yourself super-user (root) permissions in Terminal so you can use the commands needed to delete some .DS_Store files. This is done using the 'sudo' command (Switch User and Do). In terminal type the following sudo ls (all lowercase) and hit [Return] on your keyboard. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/38/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/3/38/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.6666666666667,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Terminal will prompt you for a password Use your administrator account password. If you don't have a password, leave it blank. [NOTE: For security reasons, unlike Windows, Mac OS X won't show any sign that you are typing your password, just type normally, even though nothing shows. ]{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/7/77/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Navigate to the Folder with the Corrupted .DS_Store File Method 1: Use the 'cd' (Change Directory) command along with the path to the folder in need of repair. To translate what you do in Finder to a written path, start by clicking 'Macintosh HD' on your desktop. This will become '/'. Click the next folder. The name will follow the '/' so type another '/' before any more folder names. For example, if the folder you are having issues with is 'Macintosh HD' -> 'Applications', the path to this folder is '/Applications'. If the problem folder was the 'Utilities' folder inside 'Applications', the path would be '/Applications/Utilities'. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e7/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Type cd /path (example: cd /Applications) then press Return. Method 2: We can use the 'cd' command and drag the folder to terminal which automatically completes the path building process for you. Type cd in terminal followed by a space{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4d/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4d/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Find the folder with the issue but DON'T OPEN IT, drag its icon into terminal. Watch it complete the path for you. Press Return. Delete the .DS_Store File Type rm -f .DS_Store and press Return. Terminal will ask for no confirmation and give no indication that this has been completed - it will only return a message if the command did not work. You should now be able to navigate to the folder in finder and the issue should be corrected.
sentences: Steps To delete a corrupted .DS_Store file you will need to use Terminal.app.
To do that you must be logged into Mac OS X as an administrator.
Open Terminal.
Open a new finder window and navigate to the Applications folder on the left.
(Alternately, when it says 'Finder' beside your Apple in the top left hand corner of the screen, select the 'Go' menu and click 'Applications'.

){"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/d6\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/d6\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Inside the Applications folder near the very bottom is the 'Utilities' folder.
Open that folder.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/7c\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/7\/7c\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Find and double-click the 'Terminal' application with the left mouse button to open it.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a6\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet3.jpg\/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/a\/a6\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.6666666666667,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Give yourself super-user (root) permissions in Terminal so you can use the commands needed to delete some .DS_Store files.
This is done using the 'sudo' command (Switch User and Do).
In terminal type the following sudo ls (all lowercase) and hit [Return] on your keyboard.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/38\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/3\/38\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.6666666666667,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Terminal will prompt you for a password Use your administrator account password.
If you don't have a password, leave it blank.
[NOTE: For security reasons, unlike Windows, Mac OS X won't show any sign that you are typing your password, just type normally, even though nothing shows.

]{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/77\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-3Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/7\/77\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Navigate to the Folder with the Corrupted .DS_Store File Method 1: Use the 'cd' (Change Directory) command along with the path to the folder in need of repair.
To translate what you do in Finder to a written path, start by clicking 'Macintosh HD' on your desktop.
This will become '/'.
Click the next folder.
The name will follow the '/' so type another '/' before any more folder names.
For example, if the folder you are having issues with is 'Macintosh HD' -> 'Applications', the path to this folder is '/Applications'.
If the problem folder was the 'Utilities' folder inside 'Applications', the path would be '/Applications/Utilities'.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e7\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/e7\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Type cd /path (example: cd /Applications) then press Return.
Method 2: We can use the 'cd' command and drag the folder to terminal which automatically completes the path building process for you.

Type cd in terminal followed by a space{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4d\/Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Remove-.Ds_Store-Files-on-Mac-Os-X-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Find the folder with the issue but DON'T OPEN IT, drag its icon into terminal.
Watch it complete the path for you.
Press Return.
Delete the .DS_Store File Type rm -f .DS_Store and press Return.
Terminal will ask for no confirmation and give no indication that this has been completed - it will only return a message if the command did not work.
You should now be able to navigate to the folder in finder and the issue should be corrected.
